title: COURSE NAME
text:
Welcome
This is the course book for COURSE NUMBER. This book is divided into thematic units of study to help you engage with the materials. The course resources and learning activities are designed not only to help prepare you for the course assessments, but also to give you opportunities to practice various skills.

title: COURSE NAME
text:
Course Activities
Below is some key information on features you may see throughout the course.










This box will prompt you to engage in course concepts by:

Viewing resources and reflecting on your experience and/or learning.
Checking your understanding to make sure you are ready for what follows. Ways to check your learning might include self-check quizzes or questions for discussion.

Note: Working through course activities will help you to meet the learning outcomes and successfully complete your assessments.

title: Quarto Cheatsheet
text:
Below are some examples of content that can be used in course production.

Notes
There are 2 options for notes, notes with or without icons.

Note with an icon






Note: A note with an icon





Note without an Icon






Note: A note without an icon






Blockquotes

“Your brand is what people say about you when you’re not in the room.” – Jeff Bezos



Accordions


This is an Accordion.


An accordion may contain extra content such as worked examples or sample answers. Accordions should be used sparingly.




Images
Images are handled differently depending on if they are fig-images (figures) or dec-images (decorative).

Fig-image

Should contain a caption
Should have a unique fig id (“#fig-u1_1”)
You can reference any fig-image by its unique fig id from anywhere in the course

(example: ?fig-u1_1)

Should contain alt text
Should contain source metadata (at least source-text)
May use a lightbox.

Adding a lightbox makes the image expandable with a click or tap.





Figure 1: This is a caption for a fig-image







Source: Garvin, D. A, & Roberto, M. A. (2001). What you don’t know about making decisions. Harvard Business Review, 79(8)




Figure 2







Source: Garvin, D. A, & Roberto, M. A. (2001). What you don’t know about making decisions. Harvard Business Review, 79(8)



Dec-image

Should not contain a caption
Should not have a fig id
Should contain alt text as ‘Decorative’
Should contain source metadata (at least source-text)
May use a lightbox.

Adding a lightbox makes the image expandable with a click or tap. Generally this is not necessary with a decorative image.



Source: Delicious Fresh Croissants by Efrem
Efre. Copyright: 2024, Efrem Efre. License Text:
Pexels
License.

Learning Activites
You can set the estimated time of an activity. If you do not set the time, the field will not display.


Activity: Title of the Activity






Estimated Time: 20 minutes



This is a learning activity containing an h5p activity. It has an estimated time set to 20 minutes.









Note: This is a note within an activity.



Questions to Consider

Is this a question?
Is this a second question?

Watch: The Art of Choosing







Case Study Example






It is unnumbered, so it won’t interfer with activities numbering, but display on the right hand side as part of the table of content.
This design is created for case study intention, but open to other usage.





Quiz Example
We create Quarto quizzes in replacement to H5P quizzes or PDF format. It is manual work, so please send in content early. For next iteration, we will add a carousell format to it.
Please note that the quiz response is not saved. Below is a shortened version. For existing course examples, see LDRS 504 5.2.2 and 5.5.1.










Instructions: For each statement below, rate how often you personally engage in or observe these behaviours in your groups or teams. Use this scale:
1 = Rarely or never 2 = Sometimes 3 = Often 4 = Almost always


1. Listen carefully to others, seeking to fully understand their message, including emotions and intent, before responding.


 Rarely or never Sometimes  Often Almost always



2. I avoid communication that makes others feel defensive, such as criticizing or controlling language.


 Rarely or never Sometimes  Often Almost always



3. I am aware of my own emotions during group interactions and try to manage them constructively.


 Rarely or never Sometimes  Often Almost always



4. I encourage open discussion of different viewpoints, even when there is disagreement or conflict.


 Rarely or never Sometimes  Often Almost always



5. I welcome and respect minority opinions or dissenting views in group decisions.


 Rarely or never Sometimes  Often Almost always



How to Interpret Your Results
Step 1: Calculate Your Average Score
Add your scores for all 5 statements and divide them by 5 to find your average.
Step 2: Reflect on Your Average










Average Score
Interpretation
Reflection Questions




3.5 – 4.0
Consistently Ethical



You regularly practice behaviours that promote ethical and effective group interactions. Keep reinforcing these strengths!
What specific habits help you maintain this level? How can you support others in your group?



2.5 – 3.4
Moderate Practice



You sometimes engage in these ethical behaviours but there is room for growth.
Which areas do you notice the most inconsistency? What small changes can you make to improve?



1.0 – 2.4
Needs Attention



You rarely or only occasionally use these behaviours, which may hinder ethical group dynamics.
What barriers prevent you from practicing these behaviours? What support or resources would help you develop them?






Step 3: Look at Individual Items Identify any statements where you scored below 3. These might be key focus areas to develop, as they represent critical aspects of ethical group interaction.
Step 4: Set a Personal Goal Choose one or two behaviours to focus on strengthening in your next group experience. Consider how you might apply supportive communication, emotional intelligence, or encourage minority opinions more actively.
Reflection Questions (Optional)

Which of these areas do you feel strongest in?
Which areas could you improve to promote more ethical group interactions?
How might you practice supportive communication or encourage productive conflict in your next team meeting?







Formula Example

\[
z=\frac{68-70}{12}
\]
\[
95\%CI = \text{mean} \pm (SE \times 1.96)
\]


Mermaid Examples

Flowchart






flowchart LR
    A[Actions to take] --- B[Use open peer reviews to hold people accountable.]
   A --- C[Manage at the level of the team rather than the individual.]
   A --- D[Provide development advice through continuous assessments.]
    B --- E[Evaluate with the team, as a team, providing both positive and negative feedback and hearing from all parties.]
    C --- F[Have open discussion rather than secret meetings.]
    D --- G[Meet regularly and provide feedback often.]









State Diagram






stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Still
    Still --> [*]
    Still --> Moving
    Moving --> Still
    Moving --> Crash
    Crash --> Crash1
    Crash --> [*]









Tabs
Tabs are only compatible with content displayed on Quarto site, not Moodle.

Tab ATab B



Artists have an uncanny ability to make things seem real. The potential for ‘trompe-l’oeil’ like this train coming out of the wall seemed as dangerous to the ancients as portraying something imperfectly and thus damaging our understanding of it. Art is out of control!



Some ancients believed art functioned like a false front, only showing part of something or being inherently deceitful.





Summary






Checking Your Learning



Before you move on to the next unit you may want to check that you are able to:

Describe the place of leadership in results
Explain the discipline of results-based leadership
Contrast a team-based leadership style with other approaches to leadership
